Tendonitis ?????

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎09-27-2012 12:00 PM

My hands are still acting up and haven't improved much.  My PCP said she thinks it's tendonitis, but unusual that it's in both hands.  I type with both hands, so maybe that's why.

 

Has anyone ever had tendonitis, and if so what was done for it and how did treatment work?  

 

Just what I need another "itis"! 

 

Lizzy

Knowledge is Power!

‎09-27-2012 12:36 PM

My tendonitis flares up a lot, especially when tripping pipe, I have to pull with a rope a pipe 64 ft tall weighing over 1500 #. After doing this a few days in a row, my arms n tendons kill me. Doc just tells me to find a different job. When it gets real bad, I flex my hands from closed fist to wide open. Plus a few ibuprofens. Thats all I know to do Lizzy. Doc said he could give me pain pills, but at the rig, I need to be as clear headed as possible.
T2 one year
metformin 500 2x
Lantus 24 units
Vit d 5000 iu
Vit B complex
Amyltriptiline 75 mg
Alpha lipoic acid 600 mg a day
6-12 habeneros a day

‎09-27-2012 01:07 PM

I have it and it has become chronic, been happening for the last 4-5 years.  Wish I knew how to get rid of it.  I've had injections that generally didn't provide much help and I have a TENS unit that makes it worse.  I've also tried physical therapy for over a month and it did very little to improve things.  If you find something that works let me know.

 

Tom

Diagnosed T2 October, 2009  A1c 6.8
Currently on Metformin ER 1000mg per day
Last A1c 09/21/2013  5.4

‎09-27-2012 02:18 PM

Lizzy,

 

I’m sorry to hear the diagnosis your PCP thinks it might be.  I hope you are able to find relief soon.  

 

I had problems with my shoulder awhile back.  Doc said it was tendinitis.  Wanted to give me a steroid shot.  Despite my very limited range of motion for quite some time, I tried acupuncture first, as that cured my painful trigger finger. 

 

After the 10 treatments were over, and a few months following, the range of motion began to increase and the pain decreased.  I could actually scratch my own back again.  

 

However, my acupuncturist didn’t think it was tendinitis.  The Chinese refer it to the “after 50” ailment.  Also been called “frozen shoulder”.   

 

Not sure if this information helps, but thought I’d share it.  

 

Take care of those hands and not stress them too much.  Take lots of breaks in-between all the work you do on the keyboard.   Try to stretch & clench those fingers regularly to keep them from getting stiff.   (just my personal thought) 

 

d2

Determined2 ...
 

A1c at diagnosis: 1/15/11 = 6.3 ... Most Recent: 6/04/13 = 5.6
Diet & Exercise, Metformin ER-500m & Lovastatin 10m.
+ Encouragement & Tips from Members of the Board!

I've been reading about tendonitis as a side-effect of the antibiotic Cipro that I've been taking the last few days.  I don't think I even want to get started on discussing it or add to anybody's paranoia, including my own

"Molly" (aka mollythed)

Re: Tendonitis ?????

‎09-27-2012 03:15 PM

Thanks for the comments.

 

I read up on tendonitis, and it doesn't sound exactly like what I have.  Sometimes both hands ache like a toothache, but the main problem is that the ring finger on my left hand "locks" bent and I have to literally take the other hand to unbend it.  The middle finger on my right hand sometimes won't bend, which can be a bigger problem since if I go out people might think I'm making an obscene gesture at them!

 

Being familiar with arthritis () it has qualities of that, except for the locking part.

 

Acupuncture is way out of my price range, too bad but it is what it is.  It's a shame that things that would be helpful are out of range for many people to afford.  I'm very familiar with it, and have had it in my more prosperous days.  I know it can help.

 

Guess I'll have to go to a specialist, I just don't want them to try to push a lot of drugs on me since I have bad reactions to many drugs because of the fibromyalgia.   Sometimes the cure(drug) is worse than the condition, at least in my case.

 

Lizzy  

Knowledge is Power!

‎09-27-2012 03:27 PM

lizzylou wrote:

Thanks for the comments.

 

I read up on tendonitis, and it doesn't sound exactly like what I have.  Sometimes both hands ache like a toothache, but the main problem is that the ring finger on my left hand "locks" bent and I have to literally take the other hand to unbend it.  The middle finger on my right hand sometimes won't bend, which can be a bigger problem since if I go out people might think I'm making an obscene gesture at them!

 

 

Yup, that does sound more frustrating that the twitch in my right index finger that can actually do a left mouse click for me sometimes when I don't expect it.  I think mine is a nerve problem that also can make my thumb freeze up and curl into my palm at times.

 

The origin may be completely different, but the only things that help me are massage and soaking my hands in very warm water. My husband appreciates the break from dishwashing I guess

"Molly" (aka mollythed)
Type 2 diabetes diagnosed in 1995, now managed with Lantus, Novolog and Metformin; diet and exercise.

‎09-27-2012 07:08 PM

lizzylou wrote:

Thanks for the comments.

 

I read up on tendonitis, and it doesn't sound exactly like what I have.  Sometimes both hands ache like a toothache, but the main problem is that the ring finger on my left hand "locks" bent and I have to literally take the other hand to unbend it.  The middle finger on my right hand sometimes won't bend, which can be a bigger problem since if I go out people might think I'm making an obscene gesture at them!

 

Yes, the stiff expressive finger can be a social problem ... but on a serious note, you're right, the symptoms does sound more like arthritis.  Do you know of a specialist in Arthritis you could contact? 

 

Being familiar with arthritis () it has qualities of that, except for the locking part.

 

Acupuncture is way out of my price range, too bad but it is what it is.  It's a shame that things that would be helpful are out of range for many people to afford.  I'm very familiar with it, and have had it in my more prosperous days.  I know it can help.

 

I think more carriers are slowing moving towards alternative therapies these days ... (even Kaiser has a few on board now!)  Hopefully it'll be a matter of time before they'll be as accessible as Chiropracters have been in recent years.   It'll be a much better place when medicine as we know it will finally embrace alternative practices and give us the option to choose.  

 

 

Guess I'll have to go to a specialist, I just don't want them to try to push a lot of drugs on me since I have bad reactions to many drugs because of the fibromyalgia.   Sometimes the cure(drug) is worse than the condition, at least in my case.

 

Yes Lizzy, go with an open mind and see what they say.   Take care!  d2

 

Lizzy  

 

Determined2 ...

‎09-27-2012 07:48 PM

Have tendonitis in both hands and wrist. They go away when I wear braces off and on so that my wrist are in a neutral position.  I try not to wear them too much or you will get muscle weakness.  So I wear the short braces when I sleep because I always wake up curled up.  And in pain.  Not carpal tunnel that was ruled out.  I have my hands up on my chess when I walk around because edema makes it worse.  Then I am o.k. for a couple of months and it comes back then I do it again.  Seems to be worse in the summer.  Diurectics help,  I am on lasix.  So I may take a little extra during a bad event and extra potassium.  

__________________________________

Just call me Mary
.
----------------------------------------------------------

Last A1C 6.7 March 2015
Diabetic since 6/2010. Type 2
Humalog sliding scale
Allergic to Levemir back on Lantus 28 units
Allergic to most oral and inject-able diabetic medications. Allergic to most artificial sweeteners. IPMN
Diet and exercise to control blood sugar.





How is diabetes diagnosed: http://www.diabetes.org/diabetes-basics/diagnosis/?referrer=https://www.google.com/

How to use insulin: Think Like a Pancreas

New Mantra: The least amount of food I eat, the healthier I am.
